name: Theory and Design of Writing Instruction
base_name: Theory and Design of Writing Instruction
long_desc: This course introduces prospective and developing teachers to the most meaningful questions we can ask from the writing classroom how do we design and sequence reading and writing tasks relevant to diverse learners How do we teach writing so that students can effectively adapt their strategies to new writing situations What knowledge about writing processes and texts should teachers have to design meaningful, culturally relevant learning experiences for developing writers How do we assess what our students have learned, and how do we assess the fairness of our methodsWe will approach these questions by reading from a variety of disciplines, including writing studies, second language writing studies, educational psychology, and instructional design. First we will conceptualize learners as readers and writers who bring diverse experiences and abilities to the classroom. We will then grapple with the questions about what we should teach our students, or which genres should students learn to write. To clarify the what question, we will consider frameworks from genrebased pedagogy, corpusbased pedagogy, and antiracist pedagogy as they apply to teaching FirstYear Writing and across disciplines. Finally, we will employ instructional design principles so that students will develop and situate their own pedagogical interventions within an existing curriculum that they have selected. Regular course requirements include brief synthesis papers of the course readings and a final project developed according to students particular interests.

custom_fields.goals:
Connect a view of writing knowledge and expertise with a developmental model of learning
Apply theories of learner, context, and genre for designing writing instruction.
Distinguish between researchbased teaching practices versus trialanderror teaching practices
Explain core principles of instructional design and apply those principles to your own lesson plans and methods for writing instruction.
Employ theories of composition and pedagogy to analyze the affordances of particular instructional tools for diverse learners e.g., rubrics, technologies
Develop a flexible toolkit for designing courses that you will be able to use beyond the boundaries of our current context
custom_fields.key_topics:
Writing instruction

custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Students should have a desire to teach reading and writing within the university context, but no teaching experience or instructional design experience is necessary before taking this course.

Final Projects & Presentations
custom_fields.relevance: The course is required for PhD students because they will be teaching at CMU. M.A. students use this course to market themselves for teaching jobs or to investigate whether teaching is something they would like to do
